Headline.Para: Scheme in schools spots kids, families in need of help

LeadPara.Para: Under protocol, schools know how and when to refer needy to agencies for appropriate aid

Something was eating the primary school girl. So when she confided in her school counsellor that she was afraid of her older brother because he had been rough with her, the school alerted Fei Yue Community Services' Family Service Centre in Choa Chu Kang.

TailParas.Para: Social worker Lin Feng was then roped in to investigate because the school feared there could be incidents of violence in the girl's home. But Mr Lin learnt it was a one-off incident and the parents were alerted to prevent a repeat of the incident.

Thanks to a protocol first piloted towards the end of 2014, schools know how and when to refer schoolchildren, and their families, to family service centres and social service offices. Family service centres are run by charities and they provide counselling and other aid to families, while social service offices are government-run and administer government financial aid schemes to the needy.
Minister for Social and Family Development Desmond Lee said earlier this month that the referral protocol was jointly developed with the Ministry of Education (MOE).

The two ministries had been exploring ways to boost the support given to schoolchildren from vulnerable families who could be facing multiple problems and were in need of support from various agencies.

Some of the youngsters also showed antisocial behaviour. Once such a child is identified, the school would contact his parents to get the consent to refer him to a family service centre. The centre would then work with the family to learn about its challenges and find ways to tackle them.
Referral protocol rolled out to 208 schools to date

To date, 208 schools have adopted the referral protocol, which will be rolled out to all primary and secondary schools and junior colleges under MOE's purview by the end of the year. Last year, schools referred about 900 cases to family service centres and social service offices to address parenting and financial issues, and youth behavioural problems.

The referral protocol is part of the Ministry of Social and Family Development's move to boost the delivery of social services so that the needy can get appropriate help. Among other things, this can be achieved through more sharing of information between agencies and better coordination of services, Mr Lee told Parliament during the debate on his ministry's budget earlier this month.
At the Sengkang Family Service Centre, social workers say they often get referrals involving students who play truant, with some having skipped school up to a few months at a stretch.
Problems at home often contribute to children's truancy. For example, the families may have been forced to move often because they do not have their own home due to financial problems.
Ms Esther Ng, the centre's assistant senior social worker, said: "These families are beset by so many problems and, without guidance, going to school for the child may not be a priority."

The referral protocol is also useful as it sets common standards. That way, everyone in the system - from school staff to social workers - knows what to do when they come across a student who needs help, said Mr Ian Peterson, cluster director of family and community services at Care Corner Singapore. With better coordination between schools and family service centres, more families can be saved from falling through the cracks, he added.

Social worker Calvin Ho from Fei Yue's Choa Chu Kang Family Service Centre said the protocol enables problems to be detected earlier, adding: "We want to intervene at an earlier stage, to address... problems as early as possible to prevent them from worsening."
